column2: Following the Path of a Forest Monk
Sol Hanna interviews Ajahn Pasanno about his life as a monk for the [Treasure Mountain Podcast](https://treasuremountain.stream/).

column6: Text
What was it like growing up in such an isolated place? Did this influence you towards spiritual or philosophical inquiry from a young age?
After you grew up and went to college, you travelled around the world and ended up in Thailand. What set you off on this journey around the world?
What attracted you to Thailand?
Did you go on a retreat in Thailand? How did you end up ordaining in Bangkok?
How did it come to be that you ended up with Ajahn Chah? What was it like the first time you met him?
(To himself)|Five years if five years. You've got to do it.|
As Westerners, we don't like the idea of committing, certainly not for life.
"Commitment is anathema."
Were there any memories from that period of training with Ajahn Chah that really stand out in your mind? In what ways did you find it difficult?
It was difficult, but it was also very satisfying. It felt like exactly what I wanted to be doing and should be doing.
There were quite a few Westerners who went to train in Thailand at the time. Not all of them made it. What got you through that period of time? What kept you going?
How did you come to be abbot of Wat Pah Nanachat?
How did you feel about it?
Under your leadership, Wat Pah Nanachat grew in size and more monks came to practice there.
"I think I did okay."
You were quite involved in Ajahn Chah's funeral as well. I heard that a million Thai people visited during the funeral period.
How do you think it went?
As abbot of Wat Pah Nanachat, you were involved in a model reforestation project. How did this come about and what motivated you to promote reforestation in Thailand?
It's not just forest that you want to pay attention to....The villagers need to make a living.
I had good people helping me. It wasn't just me.
How did you come to join Ajahn Amaro as co-abbot of the newly established Abhayagiri Monastery in California?
What was it like establishing a forest monastery with the strict Vinaya of the Forest Tradition in California in the 1990s?

Abhayagiri is not near a major city, but there has been plenty of interest from both laypeople and those wishing to ordain. What do you credit for the sucessful establishment phase of Abhayagiri Monastery?
We are what we say we are. That helps.
How many monastics are there at Abhayagiri right now?
During your time in the United States, how do you think the knowledge and practice of Buddhism has changed?

In 2018 you stepped away from the role of abbot of Abhayagiri, passing the role to Ajahn Karunadhammo and Ajahn Ñāṇiko. Both these monks are American and have mostly trained in the United States at Abhayagiri. How do you feel about this milestone?

You've lived a life dedicated to the spiritual quest of a Buddhist monk. What advice would you give to someone who's starting out on the Eightfold Path and may have an interest in ordaining as a monk or nun?
